titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Heard Mr: Williams from Weymouth— Bathed— Walk’d over the hills with my father in the afternoon— Mr: Boylston Adams and his sister here in the evening— I read Plutarch’s treatise upon babbling, and letters of Madame de Sevigné.

2. Return’d to town this morning— Mr: W. Cranch dined with us and went out to Quincy after dinner. I pass’d the remainder of the day at my Office, and forgot to attend at the Bankrupt-Office— Third meeting for P. N. Brown— In the evening, read part of Pope’s Dunciad to the ladies.

3. Spent the day at my Office. Excepting an hour in the afternoon, upon W. Allis’s certificate at the bankrupt Office. Walk’d in the Mall— Read this evening to the Ladies two Acts of Shakespear’s Hamlet— Answered J. Thomas’s letter— Also an invitation from the Committee of the town of Plymouth, to deliver their next Anniversary address, on the landing of our fore-fathers.

4. W Shaw went to Atkinson, to spend a few days with his mother— My Mother and Louisa Smith were in town, and dined at Mr Storer’s.— At the bankrupt Office this afternoon, and executed a certificate in the case of Benjn: Faxon— Walk in the Mall— Club at Dr: Warren’s— He was called away to President Willard at Cambridge, who is very ill.— I finish’d the epitaph again for Quincy.

5. Third meeting of the Commissioners, in the case of Biglow and Beale— Rest of the day at my Office— Mr: Gardner there— And in the afternoon my old friend Bridge, called. Just arrived from Augusta.— Walk’d in the Mall this evening.— Coll. May, and Mrs: De Neale, paid a visit to Mrs: Johnson, and pass’d an hour here.—

6. Signed at the Commissioners office, the first certificate for Bigelow and Beale— Remainder of the day at my Office— In the afternoon Dr: Dexter and Judge Davis call’d at my Office, to consider of a report to the Academy concerning the proposal from the New-York Society for the promotion of Agriculture Arts and Manufactures— We did not come to a final determination— Evening at home, and read the 3d: & 4th. Acts of Hamlet to the Ladies.

7. Signed first certificate for Amos Blanchard at the bankrupt Office, this morning at 9. Mr: Bridge called and pass’d a couple of hours at my Office— Mr: Gardner afterwards there— Went out with him in the afternoon; walk’d from his house to Quincy.

8. Bathed this morning at the wharf below Mr: Black’s— Heard Mr: Whitney.— Mr: W. Cranch, and my Uncle Adams’s family here at dinner— I read three short treatises of Plutarch, upon Avarice, Parental love, and Numerous friends, and a few of Sevigné’s letters.

9. Return’d to Boston this morning, with Mr: Briesler.— Mr: Shaw return’d likewise from Atkinson— Day at my Office— Mr: Smith and Mr: Babcock were there in the course of the forenoon— At the bankrupt Office, 3d: meeting in the case of Jos: Callender at 4. p.m.— A troublesome case— Several debts upon usurious interest rejected— Walk’d in the Mall, at the beginning of the evening.— Read the last Act of Hamlet to the ladies

10. Mr: Gardner called at my Office this forenoon, and dined with me. The Supreme Court this day began their session, but I did not attend— Walk in the Mall— Evening at Mr: Bartlett’s, with a company of ladies and gentlemen.

11. Attended by invitation of the Selectmen their visitation of the Schools— At the South, North and central Schools, there are about seven hundred boys and five hundred girls— At the Latin School, not more than fifty boys— It was past 3. p.m. before we finish’d— After which we went and dined at Faneuil-Hall— I called in the afternoon at the Supreme Court which is in Session— The club this evening were at my house; by request of Mr: Welles, whose lady is very ill— Mrs: Johnson, Mrs: Adams, and Caroline pass’d the evening at Mr Coolidge’s.

12. At the bankrupt Office this morning at 9.— 2d: meeting for N. H. Richardson. Attended at the Supreme Court the remainder of the day; heard several trials.— In the Mall towards Evening.— At home: read to the Ladies, three Acts of Congreve’s Mourning Bride— They thought it very insipid in comparison with Shakespear.

13. At the bankrupt Office this morning. Signed a certificate for P. N. Brown. Afterwards attended the Supreme Court— Mr: Babcock at my Office before dinner.— Mr: Boylston likewise. Mr: Gardner in the afternoon. We had company at home this evening.

14. At the Supreme Court, and at the bankrupt Office in the forenoon— After dinner went out to Quincy. J. Gardner went with me— Mr: Shaw went in his Chaise— Mrs: Adams could not go, the child being unwell; as he has been these ten days.

15. My mother was taken very ill in the night, and was confined all day to her bed. She sent for Dr: Tufts, who came over in the afternoon— Rained, the greatest part of the day— Read Plutarch’s treatises upon Fortune, Envy and Hatred, and how to derive benefit from our enemies— Also Madame de Sevigné—Vol 2.

16. Return’d to Boston early this morning, with Mr: Shaw— Walk’d part of the way— Left my mother still very unwell, and found my child so.— Attended the Supreme Court— Assignment of N. H. Richardson’s effects at 5 in the afternoon— Mrs: Welsh and her daughters were here in the evening— And the Dr: likewise called. I read to the ladies the remainder of the Mourning Bride.

17. Attended the Session of the Supreme Court, part of the day. Remainder at my office— Walk in the Mall towards Evening; and afterwards at home— Play’d Boston with the Ladies— Weather excessively warm and sultry— The dog-days are almost insupportable.

18. At the bankrupt Office and signed three certificates.— Attended at the Supreme Court, but not with much attention— Walk with Mrs: A in the Mall— Club at R. Amory’s.— Weather oppressive— Mr: Storer called at my Office in the forenoon.

19. The child was so ill that he kept us up great part of the night— I rose this morning very late— At the bankrupt Office— Signed the second certificate of Bigelow and Beale— Attended part of the day at the Supreme Court— In the evening, began reading to the Ladies The siege of Damascus, a tragedy by Hughes; but found it too dull to proceed— Then read two Acts of Lee’s Theodosius, which was not much better— Though we found this diverting, and full of mirth.

20. Child ill again— Rested but indifferently— Attended the Supreme Court, only a small part of the day. Spent the remainder of it, at my Office— Walk in the Evening; and afterwards read an Act of Romeo and Juliet to the Ladies

21. At the Bankrupt Office, and signed a second certificate for A. Blanchard— Remainder of the forenoon at my Office— Dined at Mr: Jonn: Jackson’s, with the Governor, Lieutt: Governor, Chief Justice Dana, and a company of fourteen or fifteen Gentlemen— The Rest of my family dined at Mr: Smith’s— In the Evening I went with J. Gardner out to Quincy— W. Cranch called at my office this forenoon.

22. Bathed at the wharf this morning— Heard Mr: Whitney of Hingham, the whole day.— Read a treatise of Plutarch on the question “how to ascertain whether we have improved in Virtue”; and finished the second Volume of Madame de Sevigné’s letters— My uncle Adams here in the evening.
23. Return’d to Boston this morning, with Dexter in the Chaise— Mr: Cranch called upon us. The Supreme Court adjourned this afternoon without day.— Walk in the Mall— Evening at home.

24. A day of excessive heat— Third meeting for Nathl: H. Richardson, at the bankrupt-office.— At my Office, remainder of the forenoon— Afternoon and evening principally at home.— Walk’d with the ladies in the Mall. Call’d at Dr: Thacher’s, and gave him the report of the Committee of overseers for the arrangements at Commencement.

25. Commencement day— Being not very well, and expecting an excessively warm day I did not go to Cambridge— Mrs: Adams and the family, went with Mr: Shaw— I spent the day principally at home, and at my Office— Walk’d in the Mall this Evening— Mrs: Adams return’d from Cambridge at about dusk— Received letters from Mr: Murray and from my brother.

26. Another extremely warm day.— Called at the Hall of the Historical Society, at noon, and found Dr: Elliot there— The meeting of the Society was at 4 o’clock in the afternoon, and I attended it. Mr: Boylston was at my Office in the forenoon— I can read little or nothing at this extremity of the season.

27. Morning at my Office— Dined with the family at Sheriff Allen’s, with a company of 25 ladies and Gentlemen. A number of Strangers— Among the rest, Mr: De Saussure of S. Carolina, his lady and daughter— And also Coll: Humphreys and his lady— Evening at home.
28. At Mr: Quincy’s, with a Committee of the Neponset river bridge proprietors— Dined there— I went out to Quincy in the evening, with Mr: Gardner The family went out in the carriage.
29. Heard Mr: Ware of Hingham the whole day.— My uncle Adams here in the evening— I read Plutarch’s discourse, comparing atheism and superstition, and wrote a short letter to my brother.

30. I came into Boston, with Mr: Gardner— Mr: Shaw came in also— The ladies and child remain at Quincy. At noon, met with Judge Davis, and Mr: Quincy, at Mr: Tudor’s, to examine his accounts as treasurer of the Historical Society.— Mr: Gardner dined with me. Rest of the day, at my Office, walking, and at home.

31. Day at my Office— Captn: Loud, and Mr: Elihu White, there all the afternoon— Called at Judge Sullivan’s, at whose house the adjourned meeting of the Historical Society was to have been held; but he was not at home. Walk’d in the Mall and pass’d the remainder of the evening at home.

Day. Rise irregularly from 6 to 8. Write at home untill 10. Breakfast— Market— Attend at my Office, at the bankrupt Office, or during part of this month at the Supreme Court— Dine at 2. Afternoon spent as the forenoon— Walk in the Mall about an hour at dusk, and spend the rest of the evening at home— Except Wednesday evening’s, at the club, and Saturdays and Sundays at Quincy.
